Issues.Title: Refactor `DisplayInformation` to use `BitVector32`
Issues.Body: `DisplayInformation` has 9 fields which can be refactored into a `BitVector32` to reduce runtime memory usage.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Refactor `DisplayInformation` to use `BitVector32`" (#10825)

Issues.Title: Refactor `BindingSource` and `CurrencyManager` to use flags enum field instead of individual boolean fields

Issues.Title: The UserControl will not adjust its size when its parent form resets the font.
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

 8.0.100

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

.NetFramework4.8

### Issue description

There is a Windows form that includes a userControl. The userControl does not change its size when I reset this form's font in .NET 8. However, it works fine in .NET Framework.
here is the code example to reproduce this issue https://github.com/hyke123/winform-/blob/main/Form1.cs
### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a WinForm class.
2. Create a UserControl class.
3. Place the UserControl on the WinForm using the designer.
4. Add a button to the WinForm using the designer.
5. Add an event for resetting the form font to the button in the designer.
6. Print the height of the UserControl during form initialization and when clicking on the button.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "The UserControl will not adjust its size when its parent form resets the font." (#10828)

Issues.Title: [Accessibility] HC themes: The sub items of toolStripMenuItem show as mouse over on them in both design time and runtime
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

9.0.100-preview.2.24105.5

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Yes, it works in .NET 8.0, it's regression issue and start from .NET 9.0 P1.

### Issue description

Click on toolStripMenuItem1 to expand the sub items, there are 4 items show as mouse over on them. This issue occurs in both form designer and runtime, and occurs in both Win11 and Win10 OS.

Win11

- Target project to .NET 9.0
![W11-9 0](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/45864985/bfe6f21d-75b2-4bd8-b61d-30e5acec28ba)

- Target project to .NET 8.0
![W11-8 0](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/45864985/3fb68bb4-7647-4e60-832d-45efeca58c3b)

Win10

- Target project to .NET 9.0
![W10-9 0](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/45864985/6f760aa7-cb66-4324-b79c-4b1215a1dcc6)

- Target project to .NET 8.0
![W10-8 0](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/45864985/ad5dba11-87aa-4556-997e-b39e7ef5fb40)


### Steps to reproduce

1. Open the [WinFormsApp24.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/14176467/WinFormsApp24.zip) project
2. Open form designer
3. Click on toolStripMenuItem1 to expand the sub items and Check the status of them
4. Run the project
5. Click on toolStripMenuItem1 to expand the sub items and Check the status of them too

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/45864985/70d31c6d-d8ef-4c48-a770-f86509281f7d
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Accessibility] HC themes: The sub items of toolStripMenuItem show as mouse over on them in both design time and runtime" (#10834)

Issues.Title: Add Fallback to CursorConverter.ConvertTo
Issues.Body:
Fixes https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/10185

We had previously removed this code in https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/10005 in an attempt to avoid using reflection when converting Cursor->string. We had tried to avoid reflection by adding property `CursorsProperty` to `Cursor` to track the "string version" of the Cursor. This will work as expected when we are setting the cursor, however there are times when other processes set the cursor, in which we only have the handle available to us i.e. we cannot utilize `CursorsProperty` to properly convert Cursor->string since we will not have that information. To handle this case, we should fall back to our old code to convert the cursor properly.

Manually testing results:
![cursor](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/30007367/2e81532f-a4c9-43d6-9bdc-16dc7b987e53)


###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/10814)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Add Fallback to CursorConverter.ConvertTo" (#10814)

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/10831)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "[main] Update dependencies from dotnet/runtime" (#10831)

Issues.Title: When using "Choose Icon... " command line to add an icon, the icon is displayed in an incorrect position
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

9.0.100-preview.2.24103.2

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Yes, cannot repro in 9.0.0-alpha.1.24053.2, but repro in 9.0.100-alpha.1.24066.22

### Issue description

When using "Choose Icon... " command line to add an icon, the icon is displayed in an incorrect position
**Actual Results**
The icon is displayed in the upper left corner of the properties window

![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/108860782/9e29e74e-8d6e-402a-8691-e0b4f71a09e7)


**Expected Results**
The icon should be displayed in the correct position
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/108860782/5d14257c-3a6d-41d8-b4a8-8d7651ff7e80)


### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a Winforms .Net Core application
2. Add a notifyIcon and propertyGrid to form designer
3. Click on propertyGrid1 and change its SelectedObject property to notifyIcon1
4. Build & Run
5. Adding the icon for Icon property by using "Choose Icon..." command line
6. Observed the position of the added icon for Icon property

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/108860782/81904b97-982c-4aef-879f-786cbd2dc279
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "When using "Choose Icon... " command line to add an icon, the icon is displayed in an incorrect position" (#10830)

Issues.Title: Refactor classes with multiple private boolean fields to use flags enum
Issues.Body:
I performed a search for "private bool _" and filtered out classes with 4 or less fields, the collated and ordered results are in the table below.

I believe we can convert these to use `BitVector32` to save runtime memory usage.

| File | Count |
|--------|--------|
|System\Windows\Forms\Controls\ComboBox\ComboBox.cs|	16|
|System\Windows\Forms\Layout\Containers\SplitContainer.cs|	13|
|System\Windows\Forms\Controls\ListBoxes\ListBox.cs|	12|
|System\Windows\Forms\DataBinding\BindingSource.cs|	12|
|System\Windows\Forms\ToolTip\ToolTip.cs|	9|
|System\Windows\Forms\Controls\PropertyGrid\PropertyGrid.cs|	6|
|System\Windows\Forms\Controls\ToolStrips\ToolStripManager.ModalMenuFilter.cs|	6|
|System\Windows\Forms\DataBinding\Binding.cs|	6|
|System\Windows\Forms\Dialogs\TaskDialog\TaskDialog.cs|	6|
|System\Windows\Forms\Controls\MonthCalendar\MonthCalendar.cs|	5|
|System\Windows\Forms\DataBinding\CurrencyManager.cs|	5|
|System\Windows\Forms\ErrorProvider\ErrorProvider.cs|	5|
|System\Windows\Forms\Printing\PrintPreviewControl.cs|	5|
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Refactor classes with multiple private boolean fields to use flags enum" (#10827)

Issues.Title: Refactor `Application` to use `BitVector32`
Issues.Body: `Application` has 5 boolean fields that can be refactored to use `BitVector32` to reduce runtime memory usage.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Refactor `Application` to use `BitVector32`" (#10826)

Issues.Title: Refactor `SendKeys` to use `BitVector32`
Issues.Body: `SendKeys` has six boolean fields which can be refactored into a `BitVector32` to reduce runtime memory usage.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Refactor `SendKeys` to use `BitVector32`" (#10824)

Issues.Title: Refactor `SystemInformation` to use `BitVector32`
Issues.Body: `SystemInformation` has six boolean fields which can be combined into one `BitVector32` to help reduce runtime memory usage.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Refactor `SystemInformation` to use `BitVector32`" (#10823)

Issues.Title: Refactor `LocalAppContextSwitches` to use `Bitvector32`
Issues.Body:
All the context switches are `bool` values. We can improve the in memory density by using `Bitvector32`. Converting the 7 `int` backing fields to one `Bitvector32`

There might be issues because the flags actually have three values:
https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/9ad7f22913cf15b0b82ae027ca4a3fdf57417923/src/System.Windows.Forms.Primitives/src/System/LocalAppContextSwitches/LocalAppContextSwitches.cs#L59

So the values will need to be stored in two bits instead of one bit. This allows for 16 context switches in a single `Bitvector32`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Refactor `LocalAppContextSwitches` to use `Bitvector32`" (#10822)
